Once again the cooperation of
all students, faculty, and employees is urged in support of the

Organized Inayliena

'Stormers Ball Offers Sex
Sex and sensuality will highlight the Barnstormers seasonlaunching rally to be held in Levering Hall tonight, according to
Fred Moehle,'Stormers president.
The doors will open at 8 p.m. Scheduled are a variety show, a
short announcement of the 'Stormers program for the coming year
and an informal dance. Music will be supplied by the Blue Jay Dance
Band.
"The strong, sexy red and blue spotlights will shine through
the smoked filled room, accentuating the color, sensuality and headiness of this once-in-an-ice-age-show," said Moehle, speaking of the
variety show. He thoughtfully added that the doors would close at
8:45, to stem the expected stampede and leave the first-corners room to
breathe.
Spicy Variety
Included in the program are: a Latin American dance couple,
comedy numbers by Hopkins Freshman John Davis, two solos by the
Blue Jays, three production numbers featuring the entire cast, and a
comedy skit by Norm Feder and Moehle.
Also on hand will be Joyce Zimmerman, Miss Baltimore of
1952 to sing popular songs.
"It will be a night club type show," Moehle summarized, "and
is the first stage of a Barnstormers hurricane."
Three Major Plays
Following the floor show, the 'Stormer 52-53 plans will be
revealed. These include presentation of three 'major plays, a
weekly half hour show for WJHU, and two series of TV shows for
local commercial stations.
Moehle will also reveal the three major plays to be produced
this year.
When asked how the 'Stormers stood financially, Moehle replied
Ahat they had their full SAO appropriation of $600 to start the
year with.

PAGE FOUR

THE PERENNIAL BRICK WALL
Last Friday's dismal turnout at the Booster Club's pep
rally was another gime example of the athletic spirit that is
Hopkins—that lackadaisical spirit that has a slight upsurge
during lacrosse season, lies dormant during the summer, wheezes
and sputters through football and basketball seasons, only to
manifest itself again when Homewood thaws and Beaver Dam
seems closer than Levering's bridge-infested cafeteria.
By this we neither condemn nor condone, but merely state an
observed fact. That elusive elf which we call, for lack of better
notation, spirit, has gone through the years in close union with
sports. Man, being a competitive creature, has made a national
pastime of cheering and booing the successes and failures of the
• knights of competitive athletics. And no less at Hopkins.
Perhaps the big difference is that the rabid enthusiasts—the
rally goers and rainy day rooters—are a small minority at The
Hopkins, while at other schools, which are so often brought up as
examples, they are just a minority. We seriously doubt that they
are a majority at any school.

"Murals

Fraternities Open Season
When the first whistle of the Intramural Football season sounded, it found eight teams taking
the gridiron to give the old college
try for their respective fraternities.
'By ROD ROHL, Sports Editor

Unnoticed by many,'one of the best soccer teams that has
played at Hopkins for quite a while, will open its season today
against Gettysburg College. In past years no one has taken
much notice of the team due perhaps to what looks like a bad
record.
However, a closer inspection of this 2 won,3 tied, 4 lost record
will prove that the team is not as bad as the record might
indicate. Their two wins combined with one loss were good
enough to put them in second place in the final standings of
the Mason-Dixon conference. Breaks made a great deal of difference. Like the lacrosse team all but one game was settled
by a one goal margin.
Little mistakes right from the start hurt the Jays last year.
In their first game the team which sported six sopohomores
showed its inexperience in losing 3-2 to Towson State Teachers
College, who went on to end up in fifth place in the MasonDixon conference -winning only one other game in conference
play and losing three. Two of the three Towson goals came as a
result of penalty kicks and spelled the difference between
victory and defeat for Hopkins.
The next .Nveek Hopkins pulled one of the best comebacks that
has ever been executed in Hopkins sports history. Trailing 3-0 in
the last period due to three penalty kick goals, the Jays would
not give up and went on to score thrice and. tie the contest up.
With this game under their belts Freddie Smith looked for a
good game against a very strong F & M team but here again
small errors put the booters out of the game before the first half
was ended. The first F & M goal came when the ball slipped out
of goalie Scotty Douthett's hands and was rebounded into the
cage. The second also came from a defensive slip up. In blocking
a shot one of the Hopkins defenders deflected it just enough
so that it was out of the reach of Douthett's hands.
Once again this year the team has a great potential. CoCaptain Stan Henry who was chosen last yell': to the AllMason-Dixon first string is back along with Jim Hutchins, second
string All-American southern division. Add to this such -stars
as Gerry Williamson who despite a bad foot last year still had
a good season and was given a first All-American Honorable Mention award in the south and Jerry Strauss, one of the scrappiest
fighters on the team, who was put on the second southern AllAmerican list. Buzzie Budnitz, who was very far off the forin
he showed two years ago, neverthless was chosen to the second
string All-Mason-Dixon team.
These honors are not to be scoffed over lightly. This is the best
showing that the booters have had on honorary teams for quite a
while and shows that individually the team should have a great
potential. Wilson Fewster is faced with the problem of knitting
this group of stars into a team that will not make the mistakes that
cost them a majority of their games. So far he seems to be doing
a pretty good job of it.
In their first scrimmage of the year the booters upset the three
time champions of the Mason-Dixon conference, Baltimore
University, in a very well played game. Despite a loss to the same
team less than a week later the win is still an indication of vast
improvement. In the first scrimmage the team seemed to be
playing the kind of ball that would win them championships
whereas in the second game they made many mistakes and as
a result were badly beaten. If they were able to leave all their
mistakes in that second scrimmage, the team could really go places.
Fewster has one of the strongest attacking teams that has been
fielded here for quite a while. All the men but Ali Arman have
experience and have showed that they have definite high scoring
potential. The two most outstanding in the group are Jim
Hutchins and Buzzie Budnitz. Last year Hutchins scored in every
game and was the backbone of the attack. Budnitz after sharing
high scoring honors in his sophomore year just couldn't seem to
„find himself last year and though he played god ball never hit his
peak. If he should hit that peak this year the Jays would probably
stand high on Hie list of offensive soccer powers.
The halfback line also shows experience as well as depth.
The first three Stan Henry, Gerry Williamson, and Jerry Strauss
all played regularly last year. They are, therefore, used to each
other and should be able to form a better coordinated unit than
last year.
Even with the experience gained by these scrimmages
the soccer coach is still a little apprehensive of their lack of
experience. "The team is going to have to score three goals in our
first few games," Fewster said, "or else I think we are going to
run into trouble."

a well balanced offensive and defensive team, the Betas had just
too much power for the scrappy
KA squad. The scoring for the

Wayne Baillie, who tallied twice.

and streaked into the end zone.

to the tune of 18-2. The brilliant
performance turned in by the entire Phi Sigs team gave the opposition a rough time, but the hard
charging line of the Phi Psi's was

'Stormers Ball Offers Sex
Sex and sensuality will highlight the Barnstormers seasonlaunching rally to be held in Levering Hall tonight, according to
Fred Moehle,'Stormers president.
The doors will open at 8 p.m. Scheduled are a variety show, a
short announcement of the 'Stormers program for the coming year
and an informal dance. Music will be supplied by the Blue Jay Dance
Band.
"The strong, sexy red and blue spotlights will shine through
the smoked filled room, accentuating the color, sensuality and headiness of this once-in-an-ice-age-show," said Moehle, speaking of the
variety show. He thoughtfully added that the doors would close at
8:45, to stem the expected stampede and leave the first-corners room to
breathe.
Spicy Variety
Included in the program are: a Latin American dance couple,
comedy numbers by Hopkins Freshman John Davis, two solos by the
Blue Jays, three production numbers featuring the entire cast, and a
comedy skit by Norm Feder and Moehle.
Also on hand will be Joyce Zimmerman, Miss Baltimore of
1952 to sing popular songs.
"It will be a night club type show," Moehle summarized, "and
is the first stage of a Barnstormers hurricane."
Three Major Plays
Following the floor show, the 'Stormer 52-53 plans will be
revealed. These include presentation of three 'major plays, a
weekly half hour show for WJHU, and two series of TV shows for
local commercial stations.
Moehle will also reveal the three major plays to be produced
this year.
When asked how the 'Stormers stood financially, Moehle replied
Ahat they had their full SAO appropriation of $600 to start the
year with.

PAGE FOUR

THE PERENNIAL BRICK WALL
Last Friday's dismal turnout at the Booster Club's pep
rally was another gime example of the athletic spirit that is
Hopkins—that lackadaisical spirit that has a slight upsurge
during lacrosse season, lies dormant during the summer, wheezes
and sputters through football and basketball seasons, only to
manifest itself again when Homewood thaws and Beaver Dam
seems closer than Levering's bridge-infested cafeteria.
By this we neither condemn nor condone, but merely state an
observed fact. That elusive elf which we call, for lack of better
notation, spirit, has gone through the years in close union with
sports. Man, being a competitive creature, has made a national
pastime of cheering and booing the successes and failures of the
• knights of competitive athletics. And no less at Hopkins.
Perhaps the big difference is that the rabid enthusiasts—the
rally goers and rainy day rooters—are a small minority at The
Hopkins, while at other schools, which are so often brought up as
examples, they are just a minority. We seriously doubt that they
are a majority at any school.

Fraternities Open Season
When the first whistle of the Intramural Football season sounded, it found eight teams taking
the gridiron to give the old college
try for their respective fraternities.
'By ROD ROHL, Sports Editor

Unnoticed by many,'one of the best soccer teams that has
played at Hopkins for quite a while, will open its season today
against Gettysburg College. In past years no one has taken
much notice of the team due perhaps to what looks like a bad
record.
However, a closer inspection of this 2 won,3 tied, 4 lost record
will prove that the team is not as bad as the record might
indicate. Their two wins combined with one loss were good
enough to put them in second place in the final standings of
the Mason-Dixon conference. Breaks made a great deal of difference. Like the lacrosse team all but one game was settled
by a one goal margin.
Little mistakes right from the start hurt the Jays last year.
In their first game the team which sported six sopohomores
showed its inexperience in losing 3-2 to Towson State Teachers
College, who went on to end up in fifth place in the MasonDixon conference -winning only one other game in conference
play and losing three. Two of the three Towson goals came as a
result of penalty kicks and spelled the difference between
victory and defeat for Hopkins.
The next .Nveek Hopkins pulled one of the best comebacks that
has ever been executed in Hopkins sports history. Trailing 3-0 in
the last period due to three penalty kick goals, the Jays would
not give up and went on to score thrice and. tie the contest up.
With this game under their belts Freddie Smith looked for a
good game against a very strong F & M team but here again
small errors put the booters out of the game before the first half
was ended. The first F & M goal came when the ball slipped out
of goalie Scotty Douthett's hands and was rebounded into the
cage. The second also came from a defensive slip up. In blocking
a shot one of the Hopkins defenders deflected it just enough
so that it was out of the reach of Douthett's hands.
Once again this year the team has a great potential. CoCaptain Stan Henry who was chosen last yell': to the AllMason-Dixon first string is back along with Jim Hutchins, second
string All-American southern division. Add to this such -stars
as Gerry Williamson who despite a bad foot last year still had
a good season and was given a first All-American Honorable Mention award in the south and Jerry Strauss, one of the scrappiest
fighters on the team, who was put on the second southern AllAmerican list. Buzzie Budnitz, who was very far off the forin
he showed two years ago, neverthless was chosen to the second
string All-Mason-Dixon team.
These honors are not to be scoffed over lightly. This is the best
showing that the booters have had on honorary teams for quite a
while and shows that individually the team should have a great
potential. Wilson Fewster is faced with the problem of knitting
this group of stars into a team that will not make the mistakes that
cost them a majority of their games. So far he seems to be doing
a pretty good job of it.
In their first scrimmage of the year the booters upset the three
time champions of the Mason-Dixon conference, Baltimore
University, in a very well played game. Despite a loss to the same
team less than a week later the win is still an indication of vast
improvement. In the first scrimmage the team seemed to be
playing the kind of ball that would win them championships
whereas in the second game they made many mistakes and as
a result were badly beaten. If they were able to leave all their
mistakes in that second scrimmage, the team could really go places.
Fewster has one of the strongest attacking teams that has been
fielded here for quite a while. All the men but Ali Arman have
experience and have showed that they have definite high scoring
potential. The two most outstanding in the group are Jim
Hutchins and Buzzie Budnitz. Last year Hutchins scored in every
game and was the backbone of the attack. Budnitz after sharing
high scoring honors in his sophomore year just couldn't seem to
„find himself last year and though he played god ball never hit his
peak. If he should hit that peak this year the Jays would probably
stand high on Hie list of offensive soccer powers.
The halfback line also shows experience as well as depth.
The first three Stan Henry, Gerry Williamson, and Jerry Strauss
all played regularly last year. They are, therefore, used to each
other and should be able to form a better coordinated unit than
last year.
Even with the experience gained by these scrimmages
the soccer coach is still a little apprehensive of their lack of
experience. "The team is going to have to score three goals in our
first few games," Fewster said, "or else I think we are going to
run into trouble."
